results.content: I think it is amazing. I'm from Colombia and te second module make me to get looking forward in my job project. Like a suggest I think that you can create a module using library of Material Design (called material-ui), that gives a good appearence to the front-end. And I frequently have the problem to get import the components using " " or ' ' I have a little confussion in that, at the same with the use of './' and '../' that are using to get out the folder, but in general, in this module the items like events, props, classes, and states was very clear to me and I am result in to complete this course trying to get the goal as I need in my job. When I will finish the project I want to get some feedback from you, because it makes me to get some confidence not only in ReactJs, in Javascript that is more important. I confess that three months ago I think that learn this was imposibble especially using material-ui. But right now, I am motivated to learn to get some applications of work, like accountant software, health care software, biometric recognition software and another using ReactJs as a frontend page.

I confess that three months ago I think that learn this was imposibble especially using material-ui. But right now, I am motivated to learn to get some applications of work, like accountant software, health care software, biometric recognition software and another using ReactJs as a frontend page.

results.content:
The goods: You get to practice each "important topic" over and over until you are VERY comfortable. I really like how the instructor did that. 

The bads: If you ask a question 99% chance it will not be answered. Not a review crusher for me as I turn to Google to get the answers I need BUT it would be beneficial to have the instructor be more involved with his course. 

Tip for instructor: Add short challenges throughout the course to test us... I would also love to see 15-30 question tests at the  end of each section.
results.content_html:

The bads: If you ask a question 99% chance it will not be answered. Not a review crusher for me as I turn to Google to get the answers I need BUT it would be beneficial to have the instructor be more involved with his course.

results.content: It has a lot of content. some of the explanations are a little rough and what is supposed to be known or assumed is unknown is a little blurred when it comes to the depth of explanations for topics. There is a decent amount of explaining of what NOT to do. which can be a little confusing. I'm just glad we don't need to know the old way of doing things and if I ever do need to learn that thing, I'll be sure to look it up later when I'm already proficient in the topic as to not get myself even more confused. It's hard to extrapolate what should have attention payed to it and what is just a rough explanation of something you likely might already have learned in a simpler way so it sounds new because the explanation is rough. Idk there's a ton of content and I'm sure this guy is a really nice guy and English isn't his first language and i could never teach a course like this in a foreign language. so I do appreciate this course a lot for simply being available and for this guy to put his work out into the world. It nets positive from all angels.

results.content: This course is amazing! It covers almost everything that is necessary to be able to develop a fully working application. After taking this course I improved my skills and knowledge a lot and I have developed a nice project with very rich functionalities, which now I can show to my friends, my colleagues at work and definitely it will be a valuable asset in my portfolio when I will decide to move forward for another professional challenge. Totally recommend it to people who have a little experience with MERN stack and who likes to have fully working applications after taking a course.

results.content:
NOT OKAY! 
-> the lecturer seems to not have a clear structure of what he's presenting, he is a bit "messy".
-> he explains the "class" concept and says it is an ES6 concept - that is not true, class is a concept of the OOP world, it has nothing to do with ES6. 
-> the presentation is very unbalanced and unclear and you can easily see that he in turn - the lecturer - does not fully understand the concept either. I had to further read stuff he mentioned in order to get a full grasp of the things he said - NOT WORTH YOUR MONEY AND ESPECIALLY TIME! I would have been better of with a list of keywords to "translate" and would get the same results.
-> Oh, there's one video where the lecturer says he has to go grab a coffee - WHY WASTE MY TIME LIKE THAT?, in a different one I get to see where he stop the screen recording app from - C'MON !? 
-> Happily, I got to see other cheaper courses that were held by lecturers much better prepaired and thoughtful than this one.

Indeed, there is a lot of ground to cover, he covers it, sure, but he stutters a lot, repeats words randomly. I don't like this course at all and I'm getting very unpatient.
results.content_html:
NOT OKAY!
-> the lecturer seems to not have a clear structure of what he's presenting, he is a bit "messy".
-> he explains the "class" concept and says it is an ES6 concept - that is not true, class is a concept of the OOP world, it has nothing to do with ES6.
-> the presentation is very unbalanced and unclear and you can easily see that he in turn - the lecturer - does not fully understand the concept either. I had to further read stuff he mentioned in order to get a full grasp of the things he said - NOT WORTH YOUR MONEY AND ESPECIALLY TIME! I would have been better of with a list of keywords to "translate" and would get the same results.
-> Oh, there's one video where the lecturer says he has to go grab a coffee - WHY WASTE MY TIME LIKE THAT?, in a different one I get to see where he stop the screen recording app from - C'MON !?
-> Happily, I got to see other cheaper courses that were held by lecturers much better prepaired and thoughtful than this one.

Indeed, there is a lot of ground to cover, he covers it, sure, but he stutters a lot, repeats words randomly. I don't like this course at all and I'm getting very unpatient.

results.content:
Course has been updated (Jan 2021). Review updated (1/30/21). I have rerated this course multiple times. I am just not sure what properly represents this course. Not everyone can teach and, I find it extremely irritating to hear how often he says dumb, super simple, and stupid. Great, he knows React but as someone who is trying to learn this isn't something you want to hear over and over again. It may be simple or dumb to him but, someone trying to grasp or learn something still needs to understand. If you have never studied React to any degree this is not the first course you should be taking. There are to many things glossed over and then, if he does it again he simply states you already know this and does it super fast. For someone that knows React enough, this is not a problem. If you are new or still don't feel overly comfortable; I see this as a problem. There is an extraordinary amount of copy/pasting which for a new person is not helping you out. You should be typing every line of code over and over so that it sinks in and becomes second nature. Personally when he copy/pasted, I typed everything out myself. And can attest to the fact it becomes second nature. I don't have to think about it when creating a new component or moving from functional to class based and/or vice versa.

If you want to better grasp hooks or understand what they do, this course uses a lot more than any other course I have taken. This includes using hooks for Redux which in turn means that basic knowledge of Redux without hooks is glossed over or not shown at all. It's great to know the latest way to do something and use it but, you should also know the fundamentals of the library and, not every business will be using hooks. 

The videos are far from clean. You will listen to him talk about how he has been sick, his computer has bugs, his errors in code where he claims he turned the videos off without realizing it while fixing the code. You will watch him find websites, search through websites, basically unorganized lectures that were not cleaned up and again when watching video after video becomes annoying. You will trash your own code over and over again. Basically his teaching style is a chaotic mess and a lot of it is a "lets get this done and out kind of thing because you already know it." 

I have no issue with the fact he knows the source materials and, for someone with a foundation of knowledge would likely learn something new but, if you yourself are new I am not sure this is a good place to start. Rather a good place to come back to for a different perspective or a more in-depth knowledge of hooks.

Part of my redoing the rating for the fourth or fifth time and increasing it a half star is that on the final project, he uses versioning of the various pieces brought in through NPM. This means that if the course becomes outdated, as his previous course was, you will still be able to follow along. If for example you were to use the latest version of MongoDB versus the version he specifies, your program may not work. By specifying this versioning, it means that you will be using the same set up he is using and therefore are able to continue to follow along even if things have moved on to something newer. This is a huge plus as his previous iteration of this class just crashed out and you couldn't make it very far before his materials were outdated.
results.content_html:

results.content:
Excellent course to get started building web apps using the most common react stack. A lot of value here. Some very basic web development knowledge is necessary to understand how some pieces work together, but overall the course is comprehensive and accomplishes what it attempts to do: provide an overall understanding of how the many pieces of a web app come together in a react project. The course is more focused on front-end development than backend, which is expected since it is a "React" course primarily. 

There are some imperfections such as the minimal or lack of explanations to support some coding techniques or artifacts used by the author, but due to sheer amount of content provided by this course it is very easy to overlook its flaws.
results.content_html:

results.content: Wow... if you are looking to get started with React, look no further! I am blown away by the attention to detail and the best practices that the instructor uses. You can read the documentation for the components covered in this class and be okay, but after watching the videos you have a head-start on how to use each of them in a working application. Don't waste your time elsewhere!

results.content: Course is a great introduction into full-stack development using ReactJs, and the instructor does a great job. Personal preference but I would prefer more videos at a shorter duration, for me it just makes it easier to jump in knock out an idea or concept if I only have a limited amount of time to study.
results.content_html: Course is a great introduction into full-stack development using ReactJs, and the instructor does a great job. Personal preference but I would prefer more videos at a shorter duration, for me it just makes it easier to jump in knock out an idea or concept if I only have a limited amount of time to study.

results.content:
This course covers the latest technologies and it is updated to January 2018, which means you get the state of the art practices.
The trainer is great and the curriculum is various and rich.
In my opinion, some aspects could have been done a bit deeper (like Webpack) but there is everything you need to start  developing in React and then some.

The only down point is that the trainer does a lot of typos while writing the examples. He says it is difficult to type and speak at the same time (which is true) but I found it a bit irritating.

In the end, it is a really great course!
results.content_html:

In the end, it is a really great course!

results.content: Excellent course! I followed other React courses, so I have some basics, but I keep learning new things, new ways of doing things. The apps that we will build are rather complex and big, quite different from other courses (I am not saying it is better, it is just different). Complete beginners might want to start with smaller tutorials. Definitely improving my React skills thanks to Fernando!

The apps that we will build are rather complex and big, quite different from other courses (I am not saying it is better, it is just different). Complete beginners might want to start with smaller tutorials. Definitely improving my React skills thanks to Fernando!

results.content: So far I am really enjoying this course. I have several books on React and have done other tutorials and learning activities but none of them have explained the concepts of React like in this course. If you are wanting to learn React and get a really great grasp on the basics and how to read and understand React code in the "wild" I suggest getting this course.
